awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CHEESE: Cyber Human Ecosystem of Engaged Security Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This project from Purdue University and the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign proposes to develop a set of cybersecurity learning tools on a dynamic, publicly available, web-based learning platform aimed at bringing together a community of cybersecurity researchers, educators, practitioners and students. By presenting these learning tools exclusively through a web interface, this project aims to enable ease of use and access to security education and hands-on activities. In addition to supplementing traditional cybersecurity instruction, the broader goal is to create a cybersecurity learning ecosystem that is continually updated with emerging trends in cybersecurity research as well as recently discovered security attacks. The researchers will seek contributions in both these areas from a broad community of students and faculty at community colleges, minority-serving institutions and organizations such as Women in Cybersecurity, while incorporating reward mechanisms that encourage contribution. 

The proposed Cyber Human Ecosystem of Engaged Security Education (CHEESE) platform will employ the National Data Service (NDS) Labs Workbench and container technology to host a growing collection of user-contributed publicly accessible demonstrations of diverse cybersecurity concepts. Container technology provides completely independent work environments for each user and simplifies the subsequent transfer to other platforms with minimal effort. The NDS Workbench provides a user interface to container management, development and orchestration capabilities that greatly simplify the process of contributing and launching these containerized applications while automatically scaling resources in response to increased usage. CHEESE will engage a broad community of users ranging from faculty, high school teachers, students to researchers and professionals to request, contribute and evaluate the hosted cybersecurity demonstrations. The effectiveness of CHEESE in imparting practical cybersecurity knowledge will be evaluated in several undergraduate and graduate cybersecurity courses. Various organizations such as the IEEE, Big Data Hubs and Women in Cybersecurity will be leveraged to conduct training and outreach events using CHEESE to broaden community participation beyond the core user community. CHEESE will help develop a cybersecurity literate workforce that can learn from prior cybersecurity incidents and employ the latest tools and secure coding practices to avoid common pitfalls associated with these incidents.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary of NSF Award Outcomes

1. Research Advances:

  • Supporting partners at Purdue as they port existing Try-CybSI applications to CHEESEhub's underlying Labs Workbench platform including design review, code review, and development of documentation.

  • Collaborated with partners at Purdue on the development of the initial Carpentry-style framework for education material

  • A demonstration of a SSH Honeypot developed by Marist College was containerized and deployed as an application on CHEESEHub.

  • A novel application combining machine learning and cybersecurity was developed to demonstrate data preprocessing and the application of popular machine learning classification algorithms. The DDoS datasets published by the Canadian Institute for Cybersecurity were used to demonstrate the use of Logistic Regression to classify between benign and attack traffic.

  • Students developed and contributed two reproducible demonstrations showing different approaches to inserting bad data into AI training sets: "SVM Poisoning" and "Adversial Neural Network"

  • Students developed and contributed a reproducible demonstration of an approach to exploiting memory boundaries to access restricted data: "Heap Overflow"

2. Publications and Dissemination:

  • Recorded presentations to the 2020 Frontiers in Education (FIE) and EDUCause Security Professionals conferences.

  • A paper on Kubernetes security best practices and lessons learned from the CHEESEHub deployment was presented at PEARC '21.

  • Underlying Workbench platform presented at a lightning talk Gateways '21, with CHEESEHub as a highlighted use case.

  • A paper on our experience in developing and managing the CHEESEHub gateway was accepted for presentation at the Gateways 2022 conference. The paper describes the technical, application design, and user management challenges that the team ran into over the five years of the CHEESE project.

3. Educational and Outreach Impact:

  • Supported training and outreach activities including workshop at the ACM Special Interest Group for Information Technology Education (SIGITE) in 2020.

  • A virtual workshop was conducted on July 26 and 27, 2021. 23 Faculty members were recruited from the ACM SIGCSE community. The CHEESEHub platform was introduced to the audience and the discussion on potential use and further development were discussed.

  • A second virtual workshop was conducted for 26 faculty from the ACM SIGCSE community on Mar 18, 2022 with presentations on using CHEESEHub in their teaching as well as a hands-on session to try out the CHEESEHub applications.

  • CHEESEHub was adopted in CNIT 555, Advanced Network Security, in Fall 2022.  More than 20 students accessed the following modules as part of their homework:  ARP Positioning, SSL Striping, and HeartBleed attack.  A group of students accessed the modules on cryptography to prepare for their research project.

  • In Spring 2023, CHEESEhub was adopted again by Purdue CNIT 555 as the lab for the course. Six graduate students and three undergraduate students participated. 

  • The use of CHEESEHub in the Purdue CNIT 555 class has led to the contribution of new network security demonstrations for CHEESE.

4. Broader Impacts:

  • The CHEESE platform makes it easier to reproduce and understand the gaps in modern security practices

  • This learning process enables people to learn how to more effectively identify and mitigate potential security holes

  • Prevent users from needing to install complex and potentially dangerous security loopholes on their own machines

7. Data Sharing and Accessibility:

  • All code and lesson plans for the CHEESE project are open-source, and available at https://github.com/cheese-hub

  • Live lessons are accessible at https://hub.cheesehub.org/

  • Underlying platform is open-source, deployable, and customizable: https://github.com/nds-org/ndslabs

8. Capacity Building:

  • The CHEESE platform makes it easier to reproduce and understand the gaps in modern security practices, and enables people to learn how to mitigate them more effectively

9. Impacts on Underrepresented Groups:

  • Provide an easy-to-use platform to get hands-on experience with and learn to mitigate subtle security problems

  • Accessible by any user with a web browser - no heavy tech or hardware is needed to utilize these learning modules

10. Future Directions:

  • As new security exploits emerge, it would be nice to contribute additional lessons to demonstrate their effects and offer strategies for mitigation

  • Offering additional workshops for folks to participate and enjoy more guided lessons

Conclusion:

The outcomes of the NSF award have not only advanced scientific knowledge in cybersecurity but have also had a positive impact on the availability and access to advanced technical tutorials. The project's success is evidenced by the usage of our platform over time and the positive feedback that we have received from users. The lessons learned will pave the way for continued contributions to education in the cybersecurity community.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2023
Modified by: Sara Lambert

Summary of NSF Award Outcomes
1. Research Advances:


Supporting partners at Purdue as they port existing Try-CybSI applications to CHEESEhub's underlying Labs Workbench platform including design review, code review, and development of documentation.


Collaborated with partners at Purdue on the development of the initial Carpentry-style framework for education material


A demonstration of a SSH Honeypot developed by Marist College was containerized and deployed as an application on CHEESEHub.


A novel application combining machine learning and cybersecurity was developed to demonstrate data preprocessing and the application of popular machine learning classification algorithms. The DDoS datasets published by the Canadian Institute for Cybersecurity were used to demonstrate the use of Logistic Regression to classify between benign and attack traffic.


Students developed and contributed two reproducible demonstrations showing different approaches to inserting bad data into AI training sets: "SVM Poisoning" and "Adversial Neural Network"


Students developed and contributed a reproducible demonstration of an approach to exploiting memory boundaries to access restricted data: "Heap Overflow"


2. Publications and Dissemination:


Recorded presentations to the 2020 Frontiers in Education (FIE) and EDUCause Security Professionals conferences.


A paper on Kubernetes security best practices and lessons learned from the CHEESEHub deployment was presented at PEARC '21.


Underlying Workbench platform presented at a lightning talk Gateways '21, with CHEESEHub as a highlighted use case.


A paper on our experience in developing and managing the CHEESEHub gateway was accepted for presentation at the Gateways 2022 conference. The paper describes the technical, application design, and user management challenges that the team ran into over the five years of the CHEESE project.


3. Educational and Outreach Impact:


Supported training and outreach activities including workshop at the ACM Special Interest Group for Information Technology Education (SIGITE) in 2020.


A virtual workshop was conducted on July 26 and 27, 2021. 23 Faculty members were recruited from the ACM SIGCSE community. The CHEESEHub platform was introduced to the audience and the discussion on potential use and further development were discussed.


A second virtual workshop was conducted for 26 faculty from the ACM SIGCSE community on Mar 18, 2022 with presentations on using CHEESEHub in their teaching as well as a hands-on session to try out the CHEESEHub applications.


CHEESEHub was adopted in CNIT 555, Advanced Network Security, in Fall 2022.  More than 20 students accessed the following modules as part of their homework:  ARP Positioning, SSL Striping, and HeartBleed attack.  A group of students accessed the modules on cryptography to prepare for their research project.


In Spring 2023, CHEESEhub was adopted again by Purdue CNIT 555 as the lab for the course. Six graduate students and three undergraduate students participated. 


The use of CHEESEHub in the Purdue CNIT 555 class has led to the contribution of new network security demonstrations for CHEESE.


4. Broader Impacts:


The CHEESE platform makes it easier to reproduce and understand the gaps in modern security practices


This learning process enables people to learn how to more effectively identify and mitigate potential security holes


Prevent users from needing to install complex and potentially dangerous security loopholes on their own machines


7. Data Sharing and Accessibility:


All code and lesson plans for the CHEESE project are open-source, and available at https://github.com/cheese-hub


Live lessons are accessible at https://hub.cheesehub.org/


Underlying platform is open-source, deployable, and customizable: https://github.com/nds-org/ndslabs


8. Capacity Building:


The CHEESE platform makes it easier to reproduce and understand the gaps in modern security practices, and enables people to learn how to mitigate them more effectively


9. Impacts on Underrepresented Groups:


Provide an easy-to-use platform to get hands-on experience with and learn to mitigate subtle security problems


Accessible by any user with a web browser - no heavy tech or hardware is needed to utilize these learning modules


10. Future Directions:


As new security exploits emerge, it would be nice to contribute additional lessons to demonstrate their effects and offer strategies for mitigation


Offering additional workshops for folks to participate and enjoy more guided lessons


Conclusion:
The outcomes of the NSF award have not only advanced scientific knowledge in cybersecurity but have also had a positive impact on the availability and access to advanced technical tutorials. The project's success is evidenced by the usage of our platform over time and the positive feedback that we have received from users. The lessons learned will pave the way for continued contributions to education in the cybersecurity community.
